content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009." It introduces enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" introduces enhanced program and provider protections in Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs, including authorized screening for fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. The Act "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers or suppliers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. The Act allows the Secretary to impose requirements on providers or suppliers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening and enhanced oversight. States may be required to implement these provisions in their State plans. Actions and determinations under this subsection are not reviewable by a judicial tribunal. The Secretary may establish screening procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, background checks, and other measures. These actions are not subject to judicial review. The Secretary may establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including background checks, site visits, and disclosure of affiliations. Providers may be subject to a period of enhanced oversight lasting 30 to 365 days. The Secretary may establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and review of claims. The oversight period can be extended beyond 365 days if deemed necessary. Enhanced oversight for claims of DME suppliers is also included. The Secretary may establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and review of claims. Enhanced oversight for claims of DME suppliers is also included, with payment withholding for suppliers in identified categories or areas with significant fraud risks. A quarterly list of claims based on prescriptions or authorizations must be validated within a 90-day period to ensure legitimacy. Claims for items and services prescribed or authorized by a physician or professional will be denied until validation is completed. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on providers and suppliers in certain categories if there is a risk of ongoing fraud in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. The moratorium must not affect individuals' access to care. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on providers and suppliers to prevent fraud in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs without impacting individuals' access to care. The Secretary may suspend or terminate participation of providers or suppliers if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate. The provisions of section 1128 apply to suspension or termination under paragraph (3) for failure to cooperate with prescription validation. A civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000 may be imposed for non-cooperation. Section 1128A applies to civil money penalties. The provisions of section 1128A apply to civil money penalties, including penalties for non-cooperation with prescription validation. Amendments to the Social Security Act include provisions for State compliance with Secretary requirements for program integrity in child health plans. The State child health plan must include procedures to enforce Secretary determinations on fraudulent activity and comply with program integrity requirements. The text chunk discusses amendments to Medicare program integrity provisions, specifically relating to enrollments and renewals of providers of services and suppliers. It also mentions consultation with the Office of Inspector General in implementing these amendments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Inspector General when identifying providers, suppliers, or services at risk of fraudulent activity under Medicare or Medicaid. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must consult with the Inspector General to identify providers, suppliers, or services at risk of fraud under Medicare, Medicaid, or the State children's health insurance program. Additional funding is authorized for this purpose, and the amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act, with expedited implementation by the Secretary of Health and Human Services within 6 months. The Secretary shall issue regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment, which will be effective immediately on an interim basis. Public comments will be allowed, and the Secretary may make changes based on feedback.
